title: Will Turkey still be under a state of emergency on 1 November 2016?
possible_answers: Yes, but only in some areas
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Turkey is still actively using the state of emergency even this week: http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/10/turkey-detains-diyarbakir-mayors-161025200857643.html.

As of Oct. 3, the state of emergency has been extended for 90 days starting on Oct. 19. Erdogan says the extension "will help the government combat all forms of terrorism."  "Mayors elected on pro-Kurdish party tickets have been detained and removed from their posts, with the state appointing trustees to their municipalities. More than 10,000 teachers also have been suspended for alleged sympathies to the PKK, which is listed as a terrorist group by Turkey and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies."   http://www.wsj.com/articles/turkey-extends-state-of-emergency-1475507092
Because they are one of our allies, and since the coup attempt the President has been purging suspects from the government in attempt to hold onto power.
Saw a WSJ article from early October that said Prime Minister Gollum was extending state of emergency for 90 days.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Answered too close to deadline. Ergodan expressed "Maybe 12 months won't be enough".

Egypt was the most similar country with data I could find for a base rate. Looks like Egypt has a long history of being in a constant SOE. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_law_in_Egypt Turkey has also seen some long periods of SOE. With 14 days to go, seems unlikely for it to end, especially un-announced. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martial_law_and_state_of_emergency_in_Turkey#Imposition_of_martial_law

I agree with the other forecasts, but I don't see why Erdogan would stop at just isolated parts of the country. It makes more sense (especially if there's an opportunity fueling to further consolidate control of Turkey) to institute it over the entire country.

Erdogan seeks it, the parliament (as predicted) endorsed the extension. There are protests but I doubt they will have any influence on this matter at all and Turkey has already taken the market hits for this. Always leaving a bit of space for doubt, but it seems very unlikely they state of emergency will end.
Erdogan has still unfinished ""cleansing" to do and will not removed the regime until he is certain he has no opposition, the state in submission and under his absolute control.

I'm new at this, so I welcome feedback on my forecast. As others have mentioned, Turkey has already extended the state of emergency past November. However, there are some reasons why Turkey might not be in a state of Emergency by November 1st. One reason is that there could be another successful coup. In one 30 year period, there was an average of 1 successful coup every 10 years (http://time.com/4408850/turkey-coup-history/). So there is about a 1/36000 chance of a successful coup happening in any given day. There are about 22 days until November 1st, so there is about a 22/36000 chance that there will be a successful coup before then. This probability is probably actually lower because of the state of emergency making it more difficult for there to be a coup. So this is actually insignificant and doesn’t affect my probability judgement. Turkey could also chose to end the state of emergency by themselves, though I think this is also unlikely. Turkey is taking advantage of its state of emergency by doing things that they would be against the law under other circumstances. (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/09/29/to-no-ones-surprise-erdogan-extends-turkeys-state-of-emergency-after-failed-coup/) They have also dimissed critisism from others about these actions without budging on their policy. I think that Turkey is unlikely to end the state of emergency early and lose the power it’s taking advantage of. I still think there is some chance they will do this, about .5%. This number is low because 22 days is a very short timeframe for the government of Turkey to change their mind about this. Another reason the state of emergency could be ended early is because of pressure from the outside. The Council of Europe, which Turkey is part of told Turkey to end this state of emergency. (http://www.aina.org/news/20161008143854.htm) The Council of Europe does have some power since they can enforce agreements like the European Convention on Human rights (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights). The Council of Europe has had infuence on decisions in the past (https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jun/28/council-of-europe-writ-large). So I think that there is some chance that the Council of Europe will pressure Turkey to end their state of emergency early. I think there is about a 2.5% chance of this. Again, the probability is small partly because 22 days is a very short timeframe. So I think there is about a 3% chance that Turkey will end their state of emergency. I think it is more likely that Turkey will still have a state of emergency in some places then end it completely. As I mentioned, Turkey will probably want to keep their state of emergency, so if they are pressured to reduce this, they will probably still want to keep it in some areas. So I think there is a 2% chance that the state of emergency will only be in some areas, and a 1% chance that it will be ended completely.

Kurdish problems in outer regions might mean a really slim chance of regional state of emergency. 
The 100% predictions look really tempting.
Because it is much easier for Erdogan to have control about the country and people and he loves this.

BECAUSE THE STATE OF EMERGENCY WAS EXTENDED OFFICIALLY  FOR 90 DAYS.
We will just keep forecasting until 11-1 although we are forecasting on an event which is 100

The reason is the volatility and widespread lack of approval by the general public of Erdogan's strive to consolidate power through strange manipulations in the judiciary.
The volatile region where Kurds are becoming more and more powerful and their insurgents together with the overhanging threat of yet another coup (which could take place in near future) makes it impossible for Erdogan to ease the curfews and normalise the functions of daily life in Turkey.
But it all can change drastically.
Turkey Extends State of Emergency by a Further 3 Months

More than 100,000 have been arrested or removed from their posts, and they are building new courts to deal with the glut of defendants accused of being sympathetic to the coup. As long as the purges continue I believe they will continue the state of emergency.
State of emergency extended another three months. http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/turkish-authorities-detain-fethullah-gulens-brother-42525669

Reiterating forecast. Date: 3. Oktober 2016 um 17:20:38 MESZ Subject: Turkey extends state of emergency for 3 months - Daily Sabah Comment: 
Speaks for itself.  The only remaining issue is confirmation of nationwide or simply some areas only. Taking ALL disclosures by Turkish public officials on this issue, there is nil to marginal chance such a State of Emergency will be slapped onto limited areas.  http://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2016/10/03/turkey-extends-state-of-emergency-for-3-months
"...The state of emergency in Turkey will be extended for 3 months starting from October 19, Deputy Prime Minister Numan Kurtulmuş announced Monday..."

the situation in Syria and Alleppo is not going to ease enough this month for Russia to stand down, so Turkey will remain in a state of emergency.

Erdogan has stated that an extension would be "good for Turkey", and as fundamental factors such as completion of the ongoing purge and the issue of possible Gülen extradition are yet to be resolved, it seems likely it will be extended. An extension in local areas only seems off given that the coup attempt is not a geospecific issue in the way Syria's war or Kurdish question.
That is what Erdogan has in mind.
Because this will suit Erdogan and he decides.
Erdogan pushing for it and will get his way

I feel there is no reason for Erdogan to lift the state of emergency. Extending the current state would enable him to strengthen his hands as long as the people of Turkey feel a sense of normalcy. Based on what I have read and seen, I feel the citizens of Turkey have adjusted to the new normalcy.
Statements of the Turkish government say that there will possibly be the need of enduring the actual state.

» Extending a state of emergency for another three months would be beneficial for Turkey as it requires more time to eradicate the threat from terrorist groups after a failed coup attempt in July, President Tayyip Erdogan said on Thursday. « http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/erdogan-says-extending-state-of-emergency-would-be-good-for/3166218.html

Heck, a better question would be if it will be under a state of emergency in November 2017. No way Erdogan is letting go until he feels keeping the state of emergency is more harmful than helpful-- to him, of course.

Such a useful tool when fighting insurgents in Kurd areas, ISIS along the Syria border and domestic revolutionaries.  Why would he surrender this authority at this time?  It will not happen unless he can get something big from the EU for limiting the area in Turkey under the state of emergency. Even then the key word would be "limit" and not total.
The control and power under the state of emergency will be very hard to relinquish.    I think it will go on for awhile.
Consider that as long as Erdogan is President - and no doubt he'll somehow make himself "President For Life" - they'll be a "state of emergency".

President Erdogan has consistently fought to consolidate and expand the powers of his presidency. The aftershocks of the failed coup granted him a strong security & public mandate to ensure that each sector of the government (for example: the judiciary & military) is aligned under his leadership. A prolonged state of emergency suits this purpose.

Contra: economics and Tourism .....

Once an emergency is declared, a tendency to maintain that state fits human behavior more. There will be a lifting, but I predeidict after the new year.
Suspect there may well be a state of emergency for remainder of Erdogan's reign, which troublingly, may be the same as his natural life.

It looks likely to be extended: http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-state-of-emergency-likely-to-be-extend-with-new-ministers--.aspx?pageID=449&nID=104209&NewsCatID=429. 
I can't get a clean average on the states of emergency or martial law in Turkey, but in the past it's lasted 9 months, 18 months, or more. Three months seems very short. 
I don't see why they would limit to some areas, since they're looking through the government and military to purge sympathizers. Historically, they have done that, but I don't think it's likely for November.

Erdogan has three major reasons to prolong this (ISIS, Kurds, Gullanites). Given his popularity, prolonging the state of emergency will probably not meet much opposition. He suggested he would do so very recently.

The state of emergency is politically expedient; Erdogan will want (and has justifiable reason) to continue it as long as Gulen is outside of Turkey, and Gulen has little risk of being deported by the USA. A smaller possibility is that the national capital region will remain under a state of emergency while it is lifted for greater Turkey.
Erdogan has no intention of letting go of this opportunity quickly.

Start @ 99% & 1%. Here is why. Erdogan this weekend  hinted that the three (3) month State of Emergency declared 20/7/16 may be extended according according to various sources.  He did not specify how long such a state of emergency may be extended. (FN1).  Fethullah Gulan also spoke out this weekend claiming Erdogan is to blame for the Coup. With such a claim, Erdogan will continue to press his clean up tactics w/in the Country. Gulan also indicated, he was prepared to return to Turkey should the U.S. decide to comply with Turkey's Request for Extradition. (2). Erdogan, on the other hand while in NY made his case at the UN, that the US must not harbor a terrorist like Gulen. (3)   Aside from the recent VP Biden visit to Turkey, the U.S. has been quiet on this front.  Whether the U.S. delivers Gulan as rapidly as Erdogan would like, is an open issue.  Additionally, considering the various Syrian/Turkish border attacks recently (4), along with the uncertainty related to Gulan's extradition to Turkey from the U.S., there is a high probability Erdogan will choose continue consolidating his power domestically by extending the State of Emergency for another three months at least. I don't believe there is a chance that the state of emergency will end in Turkey. There is no reason for it to happen yet. The currency has fluctuated, but not too badly since July. I'm sure the Turkish president doesn't want to end it yet, considering his border problems, thousands in jails that may have to be let out, etc. I don't foresee an end to this til after December.

The state of emergency is unlikely to be lifted within the next 40 days, and there don't seem to be any good reasons for partially lifting it either. For comparison, France is still under the state of emergency it imposed in November 2015, having chosen to extend rather than lift it. Turkey can argue it is under a more severe and imminent threat.
Erdogan is enjoying himself entirely too much to pull the plug on this.

Any autocrat's fondness for a state of emergency is inspiring in its persistence.  The autocrat and cronies get to define themselves as heroes while behaving as much like churls as anyone can; and at the same time they can legally, although not necessarily legitimately, suppress anything that smacks of demurral.  What's not to like?   I look for this one to stick around until at least January; if it's going well for the regime, it can be extended rather longer, of course.
